Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open multiple files
2. In the Open Editors, right-click one file and select Select For Compare.
3. Attempt to right-click on a different file either in Open Editors or in the currently open folder

data.title: Add "Convert to React TypeScript" as a refactoring options
data.body: I wrote [this TS AST transformer](https://github.com/lyft/react-javascript-to-typescript-transform) to convert React from JS to TS. It's a good candidate for the new auto-refactoring feature.

data.title: Default tasks.json "echo Hello" does not work
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Terminal: Git Bash

My default terminal is `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe"`.

For some reason that I do not understand, arguments are either not passed to bash correctly, or bash does not understand them. The default command is `"command": "echo Hello"`, but bash acts as if it just received `echo` (just prints a newline). Admittedly, I am new to vscode and I've never used tasks before 1.14, so this might just be user error or the fact I'm using bash. However, I figure the default case should work.

This bug prevents me from creating a build task for Haskell `stack`. I would like to do `"command": "stack build"`, but all bash sees is `stack`. My workaround is to do `"command": "\"stack build\""`.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Delete (or rename) old `tasks.json`.
2. In the top menu select "Tasks > Configure Tasks".
3. In command palette drop-down select the last item, "Others: Example to run arbitrary external command".
4. In the top menu select "Tasks > Run Tasks..." and choose `echo` from the palette drop-down.
5. In the command palette drop-down select the first item "Continue without scanning the build output".
6. Check the Tasks terminal and notice the lack of `Hello`.

tasks.json:
```javascript
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "echo",
            "command": "echo Hello",
            "type": "shell"
        }
    ]
}
```
Output:
```
> Executing task: echo Hello <



Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.
```

This is also reproducible with using `args`, for example, the following doesn't work:
```javascript
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "echo",
            "command": "echo",
            "args": ["Hello"],
            "type": "shell"
        }
    ]
}
```

This can be fixed by passing the entire command in escaped quotes.

```javascript
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "echo",
            "command": "\"echo Hello\"",
            "type": "shell"
        }
    ]
}
```

Output:
```
> Executing task: "echo Hello" <

Hello

Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.
```


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after updating to 1.14.0
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: W10 - 16237

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Update to 1.14
2. Try build electron app again

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes


After updating to 1.14.0 I get following error when attempting launch:
Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 10000 ms - (reason: Cannot connect to the target: connect ECONNREFUSED 127.0.0.1:29840).

Tried reinstalling all modules, restarted pc


Here is my launch.json:
```js
{
    // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
    // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
    // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [{
        "name": "Launch Electron App",

        "type": "node2",
        "request": "launch",

        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app/main.js", // important

        "stopOnEntry": false,

        "args": [" --disable-extensions"],

        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/",

        "preLaunchTask": "webpack",

        "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/electron/dist/electron.exe",

        "osx": { "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/electron/dist/electron.app/Contents/MacOS/electron" },

        "windows": { "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/electron/dist/electron.exe" },

        "linux": {},

        "env": {},

        "sourceMaps": true
    }]
}
```

data.title: Ubuntu - Launching with desktop icon doesn't remember open folders

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T20:36:40.018Z)
  - Note: This was occurring on the prior version as well.
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-58-generic (Ubuntu 16.10 64-bit)
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install fresh version of VSCode 1.14.0 (cleared local cache files, ~/.vscode, ~/.config/Code)
2. Launch VSCode, open a folder within VSCode, close VSCode (either by top-right X, or Ctrl+Q)
3. Reopen VSCode from desktop icon created by installer

Expected functionality:

VSCode should reopen the previously opened folders

Actual functionality:

VSCode opens to the main startup screen with no folder opened.

I cannot reproduce this by launching a terminal and running /usr/share/code/code. However, if I close the terminal's instance of VSCode and launch one from the desktop, then close that one and open VSCode from the same terminal, the folders remain forgotten (as expected, I think).

I can provide any relevant debugging or screenshots / screencaptures.

As an update, I can confirm clicking "reload" when an extension installs keeps the folders open, for whatever that's worth.

data.title: Support External Files Provided by TS Plugin

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Problem**
Support the new external files option that TS plugins can provide: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/15308/

We currently allow TSServer plugin extensions to register themselves for custom language modes. The angular extension for example could register the angular plugin with support for the `ng-html` language. There were a few problems with the current implementation:

1. We start automatically syncing all `ng-html` files with TSServer.
1. If the angular plugin is not active, TS treats these `ng-html` files as TypeScript code
 
**Potential Fix**
On potential fix we discussed previously: add a `plugin` property on `open` requests. TypeScript would look at the `plugin` property and only start validating the file if has the corresponding plugin.

data.title: Autocomplete advanced snippet sorting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:36:31.751Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
javadebugger|don|0.1.2
java|red|0.7.0
vscode-lua|tri|0.5.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create several custom custom snippets (Examples down)

```
"playerPos": {
		"prefix": "playerPos",
		"body": "local playerPos = player:getPosition()",
		"description": "playerPos"
	},
	"objectID 1": {
		"prefix": "playerID",
		"body": "local ${1:player}ID = ${1:player}:getId()",
		"description": "objectID"
	},
```
2. when snippets created and I write on new file: player
I get over 10 suggestions as to be expected.
So first time I write out the full word playerPos to get the snippet.

Next time when I start writing: player
First 3 suggestions should be last 3 used
Then next 3 suggestions for most used snippets (don't overlap)
Rest of suggestions param/func/snippets which used above lines
If suggestion bar not filled up by now then can continue as it is right now

(of course all suggestions should start or be similar with prefix)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Autoindent inserts extra undo item, requires double undo after paste
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Here's an example of pasting something, then hitting cmd-Z to undo. As you can see, it first undoes one indentation, then undoes the paste. That's not right, since my paste was a single command, so a single undo should undo it.

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50314/28082497-eee3dfe0-6672-11e7-998a-8715249ec60b.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy something.
2. Go into a block that has a deeper indentation level.
3. Hit cmd-V.
4. Hit cmd-Z.
5. The paste remains, but one indent level is subtracted.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Allow quick open to filter on folder names by typing folder name after the file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Quick Open (using `Command P`) is a great tool. However, if you are in a framework like Rails, you'll often have files that are named the same across many different folders, particularly for views. You may have 10s or 100s of `index.html.haml` or `index.json.jbuilder` files. Being able to narrow down the file is practically impossible with VSCode without the ability to also narrow down the folder, which provides a more descriptive name.

It would be great to have Quick Open use the filter to search the names of folders to help narrow down the list and find the file quickly.

data.title: Clean up terminal settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently external terminal and integrated terminal settings are completely separate, with only 3 settings belonging to the external terminal:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/28080219-04a1dba0-6620-11e7-9ca8-fcbd2d5ed791.png)

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/30354 wants to introduce a new cross-cutting setting that belongs to both, something like `terminal.explorerKind` which will determine whether the right click context menu in the explorer will launch the integrated terminal or the external terminal. In retrospect there should never have been this separation of `terminal.integrated.` and `terminal.external.` setting keys, we should at some point deprecate them and move to a simpler, flatter format something like this:

```
terminal.external.windowsExec -> terminal.external.windows
terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking -> terminal.cursorBlinking
terminal.integrated.scrollback -> terminal.scrollback
```

We should also look into perhaps merging the execution and terminal parts to make code sharing easier and bringing the closely related components together.

Perhaps this should happen when/if the major version is bumped.

data.title: Quote marks are doubled when typing inside of other quote marks
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Create a string (eg: type a single quote ( ' )).  It's pair is created automatically ( '' )
2.Type the other kind of quote ( " ).  Its pair is created automatically ( '""' ).

Expected behavior: automatic quote paring does not occur inside strings.

This behavior is frustrating as it makes it harder than it needs to be to build strings.  For example, attempting to type the following will result in extra unwanted quote marks:
`(json_object` = "{'" + foo + "':' + bar '}'

data.title: (Hover inspecting) Make JS/TS debugging great again
data.body:
This is more a subjective plea/rant then a bug report itself.

I remember back in ~jan/2017, hover tooltips used to work very well. Even if maybe they had a more humble formatting (ex: a simple JSON.stringify of the object).

Then in some release around february or march we got things like the new node inspector protocol, and some changes in what the debug console uses as a source (in practice, making a lot of messages disappear from it, even if it is not VS code fault).

Another thing that maybe entered into account was the increase of usage of async/await (which breaks debug stacks I guess). Gets worse with TS+sourcemaps.

Since then, debugging has never been the same. Hovering over variables rarely yield something (sometimes it works, sometimes it takes a bit of time). Now I dont even bother hovering anymore, I just go straight to typing the variable in the console or in the watch.

Not to mention that using `console: "integratedTerminal"` became mostly mandatory, since who knows when you will be losing any message.

So, probably things are this way for a reason, probably I'm doing something wrong, and certainly I should help instead of ranting. Just wanted to let this out. Thanks for all the great work!

data.title: Create loader snapshots when building
Problem with HTML pretty print
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-color|anseki|0.4.1|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.1.7|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.4.3|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.3|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.7.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an HTML-Page
2. In the body, you have to use an svg tag and put in some other elements (<g> and inside <g> -> <path>, <rect> etc.)
3. Press Save or Alt+Shift+F -> wrong format (could be because of the /> ending or because vsc doesn't recognize the svg - Tag)
4. The format in my case was:
`   (tab) <svg>
    (tab*2)<g class="svgContent">
    (tab*2)<path class="..." d="..."/>
    (tab*2)<rect class="..." x="50" y="25" height="40" width="45"/>
     (tab*2)<rect class="menuStripe" x="56" y="32" width="34" height="5"/>
